abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Pathogenic variants in <jats:italic>MMAB</jats:italic> cause <jats:italic>cblB</jats:italic>-type methylmalonic aciduria, an autosomal-recessive disorder of propionate metabolism. <jats:italic>MMAB</jats:italic> encodes ATP:cobalamin adenosyltransferase, using ATP and cob(I)alamin to create 5’-deoxyadenosylcobalamin (AdoCbl), the cofactor of methylmalonyl-CoA mutase (MMUT). We identified bi-allelic disease-causing variants in <jats:italic>MMAB</jats:italic> in 97 individuals with <jats:italic>cblB</jats:italic>-type methylmalonic aciduria, including 33 different and 16 novel variants. Missense changes accounted for the most frequent pathogenic alleles (p.(Arg186Trp), <jats:italic>N</jats:italic> = 57; p.(Arg191Trp), <jats:italic>N</jats:italic> = 19); while c.700C > T (p.(Arg234*)) was the most frequently identified truncating variant (<jats:italic>N</jats:italic> = 14). In fibroblasts from 76 affected individuals, the ratio of propionate incorporation in the presence and absence of hydroxocobalamin (PI ratio) was associated to clinical cobalamin responsiveness and later disease onset. We found p.(Arg234*) to be associated with cobalamin responsiveness in vitro, and clinically with later onset; p.(Arg186Trp) and p.(Arg191Trp) showed no clear cobalamin responsiveness and early onset. Mapping these and novel variants onto the MMAB structure revealed their potential to affect ATP and AdoCbl binding. Follow-up biochemical characterization of recombinant MMAB identified its three active sites to be equivalent for ATP binding, determined by fluorescence spectroscopy (<jats:italic>K</jats:italic><jats:sub>d</jats:sub> = 21 µM) and isothermal calorimetry (<jats:italic>K</jats:italic><jats:sub>d</jats:sub> = 14 µM), but function as two non-equivalent AdoCbl binding sites (<jats:italic>K</jats:italic><jats:sub>d1</jats:sub> = 0.55 μM; <jats:italic>K</jats:italic><jats:sub>d2</jats:sub> = 8.4 μM). Ejection of AdoCbl was activated by ATP (<jats:italic>K</jats:italic><jats:sub>a</jats:sub> = 24 µM), which was sensitized by the presence of MMUT (<jats:italic>K</jats:italic><jats:sub>a</jats:sub> = 13 µM). This study expands the landscape of pathogenic <jats:italic>MMAB</jats:italic> variants, provides association of in vitro and clinical responsiveness, and facilitates insight into MMAB function, enabling better disease understanding.</jats:p>
